ʻIse·raʻela iʻoa Israel; Israeli. Dic., sp. var.

ʻita kik Ether. Eng.

ʻĪ·tā·lia iʻoa Italy; Italian. Dic., sp. var. Also ʻĪkālia.

ʻo2 Abbreviation for ʻoki hapalua (bisect).

ʻoā kik/heh Crack or split, as in a sidewalk; to crack or split. Dic. Cf. kōā. See neʻe ʻoā.

ʻoi ʻaʻ Acute, in math. Dic. Huina ʻoi. Acute angle. Huinakolu ʻoi. Acute triangle.

ʻoi aku ka nui Greater than, in math. Also nui aʻe. See ʻoi aku ke emi.

ʻoi aku ke emi Less than, in math. Also emi iho. See ʻoi aku ka nui.

 

ʻoi·hana kik Business, career, occupation; professional, professionally. Dic. Cf. kāloaʻa, pāʻoihana. See entries below and kākoʻo ʻoihana olakino. Mea hulahula ʻoihana. Professional dancer. Paʻi ʻoihana ʻia. Professionally printed. ʻOihana pōhili. Baseball career.

ʻoi·hana kik Department, office. Dic., ext. mng. Also keʻena. Cf. māhele. See entries below.

ʻOi·hana Iʻa me ka Holo·holona Lō·hiu o ʻAme·lika kik US Fish and Wildlife Service. Lit., fish and wildlife department of America.

ʻOi·hana o nā Pāka a me nā Hana Hoʻo·nanea kik Department of Parks and Recreation. Dic.

ʻoi·hana haʻi·lono kik Journalism. Lit., occupation (to) tell the news.

ʻOi·hana Hoʻo·lā·lā a me ka Hoʻo·mohala Wai·wai o ka Moku ʻāina ʻo Hawaiʻi kik Hawaiʻi State Department of Planning and Economic Development. Lit., planning and economic development department of the state of Hawaiʻi.

ʻOi·hana Kā·lā o ka Moku·ʻāina ʻo Hawaiʻi kik Hawaiʻi State Department of Finance. Lit., money department of the State of Hawaiʻi.

ʻoi·hana kā·pili kik Manufacturing industry. Sh. ʻoihana + hana kāpili. Also ʻoiʻenehana kāpili.

ʻOi·hana Kumu·wai·wai ʻĀina kik Department of Land and Natural Resources (DLNR). Lit., land resources department.

ʻOi·hana Lawaiʻa Kai Peke lala kik National Marine Fisheries Service. Lit., federal sea-fishing bureau.

ʻoi·hana lawe·lawe kik Service industry.

ʻOi·hana Mahi ʻAi o ka Moku ʻāina kik State Department of Agriculture. Lit., agricultural department of the state.

ʻoi·hana moku kik Navy. Dic. Also pūʻali kaua moana, ʻau moku kaua.

ʻOi·hana Pāka Au·puni kik National Park Service. Lit., national park department.

ʻoi·hana ani·lā kik Weather service.

ʻō·iho·iho ʻaʻ Waxy, as in texture. Comb. ʻō- + ihoiho.

ʻō·iwi ʻaʻ Indigenous, native. Dic., ext. mng. Cf. ʻāpaʻakuma. Lau nahele ʻōiwi. Natural vegetation. Manu ʻōiwi. Native bird. Meakanu ʻōiwi. Indigenous plant.

ʻoi·ʻene·hana kik Industry, especially that with a highly technological structure of production or service; industrialized; developed, as a First World Country. He ʻāina ʻoiʻenehana ʻo Kelemānia; ʻo ka hana kaʻa kekahi o nā ʻoiʻenehana o laila. Germany is an industrialized country; car manufacturing is one of its businesses. Sh. hōʻoi + ʻenehana. Cf. hōʻoiʻenehana. See entries below and ʻenehana. ʻĀina ʻoiʻenehana. Developed country; First World Country.

ʻoi·ʻene·hana kā·pili kik Manufacturing industry. Sh. ʻoiʻenehana + hana kāpili. Also ʻoihana kāpili.

ʻoi·ʻene·hana kū·kulu kik Construction industry. Inā emi ka nui o nā pāhana kūkulu, a laila, ʻike ʻia ka ʻalu nui ma ka ʻoiʻenehana kūkulu. If there are not many construction projects going on, the construction industry falls into a real slump.

ʻoi·ʻoi See papa ʻoiʻoi.

ʻō·ula·ula kik Plankton. Redup. of koura (Eastern Polynesian, shrimp).

ʻoulu kik Culture, as bacteria grown in a prepared nutrient. Dic., ext. mng. ʻOulu one. Sand culture. ʻOulu māhuaola. Nutrient culture.

ʻOhaio iʻoa Ohio; Ohioan. Dic.

ʻō·hā kai Pīʻoe ʻōhā kai. Gooseneck barnacle. See pīʻoe.

 

ʻohana kā·lai·mea·ola kik Biological family. Lit., biology family.

ʻohana ʻā·lani kik Citrus. Lit., orange family.

ʻohana sila kik Pinniped, i.e. any of the suborder of aquatic mammals including the seal and walrus. Lit., seal family.

ʻō·haʻi kik Ore. Tah. ʻōfaʻi (stone).

ʻō hā·ʻule hua kik Ovipositor. Lit., piercing instrument (for) laying eggs.

ʻohe See entries below and mauʻu ʻohe.

ʻohe hoʻo·nui ʻike kik Microscope. Lit., tube (for) enlarging sight. See aniani kaupaneʻe, paepae aniani kaupaneʻe.

ʻohe·kani puluka kik Flute. Comb. dic. (sp. var.) + dic. Also puluka.

ʻohe kī·wī kik Cathode-ray tube (CRT). Lit., TV tube. See ʻūholo uila ʻine.

ʻohe·nā·na kik Telescope. Dic., sp. var. Paʻa ʻohenānā. Binoculars.

ʻohi ham To collect, as fingerprints at the scene of a crime. Dic. ʻOhi i ka meheu manamana lima (māka manamana lima, kiʻi manamana lima). To collect fingerprints. Cf. kāpala. See entries below and hano ʻohi.

ʻohi hiki ham COD, cash on delivery. Lit., collect (on) arrival.

ʻohi kā·lā Mīkini ʻohi kālā. Cash register. Lit., machine (for) collecting money. Mea ʻohi kālā. Cashier. Also kanaka ʻohi kālā, wahine ʻohi kālā.

ʻō·hiki kauka niho kik Dentist's pick, probe. See wili niho.

ʻohina kik Fact family, as in math. Lit., gathering selection.

ʻō hoʻo·kani kik Tuning fork (preceded by ke). Lit., musical fork. Also hao hoʻokani.

ʻō·hua kik Extra, i.e. one hired for crowd scenes in movie or video production. Dic., ext. mng. See pepeke ʻōhua.

ʻō·hui kik Batch, as of cookies or recruits. Comb. ʻō- + hui.

ʻō·huka ʻaʻ Feral but formerly domesticated, as feral goats. Comb. ʻō- + mahuka. See ʻāhiu.

ʻOk. Abbreviation for ʻOkakopa (October).

ʻoka See palapala ʻoka, palapala ʻoka kūʻai, pepa papa ʻoka, pila ʻoka kālā, ʻoka pākahikahi.

ʻOka·kopa iʻoa October. Dic. Abb. ʻOk.

ʻō·kala kik Sea anemone. Dic. Also ʻōkole.

ʻOkala·homa iʻoa Oklahoma; Oklahoman. Dic.

ʻoka·mila kik Oatmeal. Eng. Ulahi ʻokamila. Oatmeal flake.

ʻokana See pānini ʻokana.

ʻoka pā·kahi·kahi ham À la carte, as on a menu. Niʻihau. Also ma ka ʻikamu.

ʻoka·tene kik Octane. Eng.

ʻō·keni kik Coin. Dic., ext. mng. See pepa kālā.

ʻokesa·ili·hate Kalipuna ʻokesailihate. Calcium oxilate.

ʻokesa·side kik Oxide. Eng. Kupuriku ʻokesaside. Cupric oxide. Feriku ʻokesaside. Ferric oxide. Ferousa ʻokesaside. Ferrous oxide. Ferosoferiku ʻokesaside. Ferrosoferric oxide.

ʻoki ham To cut, mow. Dic. See entries below. ʻOki i ka mauʻu. To mow the lawn. Also ʻoki i ka mahiki.

ʻoki ham To stop or break, as an electric circuit. Dic., ext. mng. See hoʻokuʻi.

ʻoki ham To record, as on a cassette. Niʻihau. Also hoʻopaʻa.

ʻokia ʻaʻ Cutaway. Dic., ext. mng. ʻUkulele ʻokia. Cutaway ʻukulele.

ʻoki hapa·lua ham To bisect, in math. Lit., cut in half. Abb. ʻo2. See kaha ʻoki hapalua.

ʻoki·kaha ham To slice off. Comb. ʻoki + kaha.

ʻoki·kene kik Oxygen. Dic.

 

ʻoki·kene kolu kik Ozone. Lit., triple oxygen. See lole ana ʻokikene kolu.

ʻoki pā·hiʻa ham To cut diagonally. Dic. Also ʻoki ma ka pāhiʻa.

ʻoki pō·kole kik/heh Shortcut; to take a shortcut. Calque from Eng. idiom.

ʻō·kole kik Sea anemone. Dic. Also ʻōkala.

ʻokoʻa Hoʻomaha ʻokoʻa. Whole rest, in music. Hua mele ʻokoʻa. Whole note, in music.

ʻOko·soka iʻoa Okhostk. Eng. Ke kai ʻo ʻOkosoka. Sea of Okhostk.

ʻoko·tio See pānini ʻokotio.

ʻō·kuene kik Layout, as of a computer keyboard. Comb. ʻō- + kuene. Cf. kaʻakuene. ʻŌkuene papa pihi. Keyboard layout.

ʻō·kuhi kik Directions. Sh. ʻōlelo + kuhikuhi. Kōmi ʻōkuhi. Script, i.e. a set of computer codes programmed to run consecutively in a computer system. Haku kōmi ʻōkuhi. To write a (computer) script; scripting.

ʻō·kuʻe·kuʻe Pīʻoe ʻōkuʻekuʻe. Acorn barnacle. See pīʻoe.

ʻō·lala See ʻaila ʻōlala.

ʻō·lali kik Glide, in linguistics. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻō·lapa heh Lift-off, as of a rocket or missile; to blast off. Dic., ext. mng. Cf. hoʻōlapa. See helu ʻōlapa.

ʻō·lapa haole kik Aspen. Lit., foreign ʻōlapa.

ʻōlē kik Horn, as on a car or bicycle. Mān. Also ʻōlea.

ʻō·lea kik Horn, as on a car or bicycle. Niʻihau. Also ʻōlē. Mān.

ʻole Kele·wine Absolute zero, i.e. a hypothetical temperature characterized by complete absence of heat; 0 degrees K (Kelvin). Lit., zero Kelvin.

ʻOle·kona iʻoa Oregon; Oregonian. Dic. Also ʻOregona.

ʻō·lelo kik Language; statement. Dic. See entries below. Aʻo kahua ʻōlelo. Language-based learning. Makakau ʻōlelo. Language awareness. ʻŌlelo ala nuʻukia. Mission statement. ʻŌlelo nuʻukia. Vision statement.

ʻō·lelo haʻi mua kik Foreword, preface, as in a book. Dic, Also ʻōlelo mua. Cf. ʻōlelo hoʻākāka.

ʻō·lelo hoʻā·kāka kik Introduction, as in a book. Lit., word (of) explanation. Cf. ʻōlelo haʻi mua, ʻōlelo mua.

ʻō·lelo hō·ʻike kik Oral report. Also hōʻike haʻi waha.

ʻō·lelo hoʻo·hani kik Hint. Comb. ʻōlelo + hoʻohani. See hoʻohani.

ʻō·lelo hoʻōho ham Exclamatory statement; to make such a statement. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻō·lelo·kona kik Talkathon. Comb. ʻōlelo + Eng.

ʻō·lelo kuhi lima kik Sign language. Lit., hand-gesture language. See kuhi lima.

ʻō·lelo mua kik Preamble. Trad. Foreword, preface, as in a book. Dic. Also ʻōlelo haʻi mua. Cf. ʻōlelo hoʻākāka.

ʻō·lepe kik Impatiens. Dic. See pukaaniani ʻōlepe, puke ʻōlepe.

ʻō·lepe·lepe See pale pukaaniani ʻōlepelepe, pukaaniani ʻōlepe.

ʻō·lewa ʻaʻ Flexible, as a policy. Penei ke kulekele, akā naʻe, he ʻōlewa nō i ka wā kūpono. This is the policy, but it can be flexible when appropriate. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻoli·ō See manu ʻoliō.

ʻoli·liko kik Ostracod, a tiny crustacean having a shrimplike body enclosed in a hinged bivalve shell. Lit., shimmering.

ʻolili·ʻula kik Aurora borealis, northern lights. Lit., ghostly shimmering.

ʻolo kik Bob, as of a pendulum. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻolo·kaʻa See paukū ʻolokaʻa.

 

ʻolo·kele kik Swamp. Dic. See ālia-lia, nāele.

ʻolo·keʻa kik Outline, as a summary using letters and numbers in headings to indicate topics and subtopics. NOTE: Only vowels with subscript numbers used as letters in outlining: A, E, I, O, U, A1, E1, I1, O1, U1, A2, E2.... Pronounced: ʻā (maʻaka) kahi, ʻā (maʻaka) lua.... Dic., new mng. See entry below and hōʻolokeʻa. ʻOlokeʻa palapala. Document outline, as in a computer program.

ʻolo·keʻa koina papa kik Syllabus, as for a college course. Lit., outline (of) class requirements. Cf. moʻohaʻawina.

ʻolo·laha kik Oval. Niʻihau. Also pōʻai lōʻihi. ʻOlolaha analahi. Ellipse.

ʻolume·pika kik Olympics; olympic. Eng. Nā Pāʻani ʻOlumepika Hoʻoilo. Winter Olympic Games.

ʻOlume·pika iʻoa Olympus. Eng. Mauna ʻOlumepika. Mount Olympus; Olympus Mons, a volcano on Mars.

ʻoma Pā ʻoma. Baking pan (preceded by ke).

ʻō·mā kik Maine lobster. (French homard.)

ʻō·maka hua kanu kik Bulb tip. Lit., bulb budding. See hua kanu.

ʻō·maka kau peʻa kik Universal fitting, for putting pipes together. Niʻihau. Cf. ʻōmaka T.

ʻō maka kolu kik Trident (preceded by ke). Lit., three-pointed spear.

ʻō·maka T kik T-fitting, for putting pipes together. Niʻihau. Cf. ʻōmaka kau peʻa.

ʻoma kō·ʻala kik Broiler oven. Lit., oven (for) broiling.

ʻOmana iʻoa Oman; Omani. Eng.

ʻoma·wawe kik Microwave oven. Lit., fast oven.

ʻo·maʻo·haku kik Olivine. Comb. ʻōmaʻo + haku.

ʻome kik Ohm, a unit of resistance in electricity. Eng. Cf. anakahi uila. Ana ʻome. Ohmmeter.

ʻomo·hau kik lcecap. Lit., ice cover.

ʻō·mole iho uila kik Battery jar, i.e. a large cylindrical container of heavy glass with an open top as used in laboratories. Lit., electric battery jar.

ʻō·mole omo wai·ū kik Baby bottle. Lit., bottle (for) sucking milk. Also ʻōmole waiū.

ʻō·mole hoʻo·kulu kik Dropping bottle, i.e. a bottle used much like an eyedropper. Lit., bottle (used to) cause drops.

ʻō·mole kā·lani kik Gallon jar, gallon jug.

ʻō·mole·liʻi kik Vial. Lit., small bottle.

ʻō·mole mā·lama ʻelala kik Insect holding jar. Lit., jar (for) keeping insects. Cf. ʻōmole pepehi ʻelala.

ʻō·mole pepehi ʻelala kik Insect killing jar. Lit., jar (for) killing insects. Cf. ʻōmole mālama ʻelala.

ʻō·mole ʻapo huna·huna kik Dustfall jar, as for scientific experiments. Lit., jar (for) catching particles.

ʻō·moʻo noho kik Bleachers. Lit., ridge (of) seats.

ʻōnae·ao kik Universe, as a scientific term only. Sh. ʻōnaehana + ao.

ʻō nae·hana kik System. Comb. ʻō- + nae + hana. See entries below.

ʻō·nae·hana ola·kino kaia·ulu kik Community-based health system. Lit., community health system.

ʻō·nae·hana hanu kik Respiratory system. Lit., respiration system.

ʻō·nae·hana hō·mona kik Endocrine system, in biology. Lit., hormone system.

ʻō·nae·hana hoʻo·heheʻe mea·ʻai kik Digestive system.

ʻō·nae·hana hoʻo·hua kik Reproductive system, in biology.

 

ʻō·nae·hana hoʻo·kau·apono kik Balancing mechanism, in biology. Lit., system (for) compensating.

ʻŌ·nae·hana Hoʻo·malu ʻĀina Kū·lohe·ohe kik Natural Areas Reserves System (NARS). Lit., system (for) protecting natural land. Cf. ʻāina hoʻomalu ao kūlohelohe.

ʻō·nae·hana hoʻo-nā ʻāina kik Land registration system. Lit., system (for) settling land claims.

ʻō·nae·hana kauka no ka lapa·ʻau like ʻana kik Coordinated physician referral system. Lit., doctors' system for treating medicinally together.

ʻō·nae·hana keki mala kik Decimal system, in math. See kekimala.

ʻō·nae·hana lō·kino kik Organ system, in biology.

ʻō·nae·hana lolo·kū kik Nervous system.

ʻō·nae·hana mā·kala kik Muscular system, in biology. Lit., muscle system.

ʻō·nae·hana māno·wai kik Cardio-vascular system, circulatory system. Also ʻōnaehana mānowai koko.

ʻō·nae hana mī·kā emi kik Low-pressure system, in meteorology. Pā ka ʻōnaehana mīkā emi ma ke komohana ʻākau o Hawaiʻi. Low pressure systems develop northwest of Hawaiʻi. Lit., waning pressure system. Cf. ʻōnaehana mīkā piʻi.

ʻō nae·hana mī·kā piʻi kik High-pressure system, in meteorology. Lit., ascending pressure system. Cf. ʻōnaehana mīkā emi.

ʻō·nae·hana pale ʻea kik Immune system, as in mammals. Lit., system (to) ward off infectious diseases.

ʻō·nae·hana pū·nae·wele kik Network system, as in a computer system.

ʻō·nae·hana ʻili kik Integumentary system, in biology. Lit., skin system.

ʻoneki kik Desktop, in a computer program. Dic., ext. mng. See entries below.

ʻoneki hana kik Payload bay, i.e. the part of a spacecraft where scientific instruments and passengers are carried. Lit, work deck.

ʻoneki pai·laka kik Flight deck, as on a spaceship. Lit., pilot deck.

ʻoni a ka moku "Rock the boat," a jump rope game of jumping and bouncing a ball at the same time. Mān. See luʻu nalu poʻi.

ʻoni·lele kik Aerobics. Lit., jumping movements. See hoʻoikaika puʻuwai.

ʻonina kik Move, as in a sports play; movement, as of body parts. ʻlke aku nei ʻoe i kēlā ʻonina? Hō ka maʻe! Did you see that move? Wow, that was sweet! Comb. ʻoni + -na. Pōʻai ʻonina kino. Psycho-motor domain, as relating to the learning process.

ʻoni-pā ʻaʻ Thigmotactic. Lit., move (when) touched.

ʻono Aʻalonoa ʻono. Taste receptor.

ʻŌ·nohi ʻUla Kū-ā·hewa iʻoa Giant Red Spot, a huge gaseous feature on Jupiter. Lit., vast red eyeball.

ʻō·pā kik Rowboat, skiff. Niʻihau var. of waʻapā.

ʻō·pae Pā·kē kik Crayfish. Mān.

ʻō·pae Pola·pola kik Tahitian prawn. Lit., Tahitian shrimp.

ʻō·pao kik Cellar. Comb. ʻō- + pao (somewhat cavernous).

ʻō·paka kik Prism. Dic. ʻŌpaka huinahā lōʻihi. Rectangular prism.

ʻopa·kuma kik Opossum. Eng. ʻOpakuma ʻAmelika ʻĀkau. North American opossum.

ʻō·paʻa kik Set, in math; also as of golf clubs or silverware. Comb. ʻō- + paʻa. Cf. huikaina. See entry below.

ʻō·paʻa hopena kik Sample space, i.e. the set of all possible outcomes of an experiment, in math. Lit., outcome set.

 

ʻō·paʻu kik Carbon, not in chemistry. Comb. ʻō- + paʻu. Cf. kalapona. Pepa ʻōpaʻu. Carbon paper.

ʻope kik Pack, for items other than drinks, as gum, baseball cards, or cigarettes. Dic., ext. mng, See pahu, pūʻolo, ʻekeʻeke. ʻOpe hā. Four-pack. ʻOpe ono. Six-pack.

ʻopi kik Crease, as on a pair of pants. Dic. Also haki. See entry below.

ʻopi ham To compress or collapse, as a file in a computer program. E ʻopi i ka waihona i hiki ke loaʻa ma ke pā malule. Compress the file so that it can be put onto the floppy disk. E ʻopi i ka papa kuhikuhi a i ke kūʻono ʻākau o lalo. Collapse the menu to the lower right-hand corner. Dic., ext. mng. Cf. hoʻomahola. See ʻopihia.

ʻō·pio Pae ʻōpio. Junior varsity, as a league of sports at school.

ʻō·pio·pio Lawehala ʻōpiopio. Juvenile delinquency.

ʻopi·hia ʻaʻ Compressed or collapsed, as a file in a computer program. Pehea ʻoe e wehe ai i ka waihona ʻopihia? How do you open a compressed file? Comb. ʻopi + -hia. See ʻopi, hoʻomahola. Waihona ʻopihia. Compressed file, collapsed file.

ʻō·piki·piki kik/ʻaʻ Anxiety. Nui ka ʻōpikipiki o kuʻu manaʻo i ka noʻonoʻo i ka holo ʻana i luna o ke kai a mamao loa. My mind was filled with anxiety when thinking about the long trip over the sea. Dic.

ʻō·pili heh To close up tight, as a flowerbud. Dic.

ʻō·pū kik Body, as of an ʻukulele, guitar, etc. Niʻihau. See ʻukulele. Mākala ʻōpū. Abdominal muscle.

ʻō·pū kik Ventricle, of the mammalian heart. Trad. Also ʻōpū puʻuwai. See entries below.

ʻō·pua Ao ʻōpua. Cumulus cloud. Comb. ao + dic.

ʻō·pū hema kik Left ventricle, of the mammalian heart. Also ʻōpū puʻuwai hema.

ʻō·pū puʻu·wai kik Ventricle, of the mammalian heart. Trad. Also ʻōpū. See keʻena. ʻōpū puʻuwai hema. Left ventricle. ʻŌpū puʻuwai ʻākau. Right ventricle.

ʻō·pū ʻā·kau kik Right ventricle, of the mammalian heart. Also ʻōpū puʻuwai ʻākau.

ʻō·puʻu kik Bulb. Niʻihau. See ʻōpuʻuahi. Ana kawaūea ʻōpuʻu pulu a maloʻo. Wet-and-dry-bulb hygrometer. ʻŌpuʻu kukui. Light bulb.

ʻō·puʻu kik Geometric cone. Dic.

ʻō·puʻu·ahi kik Spark plug. Niʻihau.

ʻō·puʻu·hame kik Clove, the spice. Comb. ʻōpuʻu + hame.

ʻowaka·waka kik Reflector. Dic., ext. mng. Also kukui ʻowakawaka.

ʻō·wī ham To peer, i.e. look narrowly or searchingly at something. Niʻihau. Also kiʻei.

ʻō·wili kik Roll, as of film. Niʻihau. ʻŌwili kiʻi. Roll of film. ʻŌwili kiʻiaka. Filmstrip.

ʻoʻa kik Green onion with a purple bulb becoming white close to the tip. Mān. (RNM). Cf. lina.

ō·ʻā ʻaʻ Mixed, combined, in math and science. Dic., ext. mng. Helu ʻōʻā. Mixed number. Kekimala ʻōʻā. Mixed decimal. Mekala ʻōʻā. Alloy. Also metala ʻōʻā. ʻŌʻā kemikala ʻia. Chemically combined.

ʻō·ʻaki kik Geometrid moth. Ua maopopo ʻia ka poʻiiʻa ʻana o ka piohē a ka ʻōʻaki i ka luapoʻi ola. Larvae of the geometrid moth has been known to catch active prey. Sh. ʻōkaʻi + ʻaki/ metathesis of ʻōkaʻi.

ʻoʻe ham To skim, as oil from the top of stew. Mān. Also kīʻoʻe.

ʻō ʻeli kik Spading fork (preceded by ke). Lit., fork (for) digging.

 

ʻoʻeno kik Twill plaiting. Dic. Also maka pūalu.

ʻō·ʻili See papa ʻōʻili.

ʻoʻopu Pā·kē kik Catfish. Mān.

ʻō·ʻū ham To abort, as in a computer program. Ua ʻōʻū ʻia ka hoʻoneʻe waihona ʻana. The file transfer was aborted. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻora·gano·poso·pahate kik Organophosphate. Eng.

ʻOre·gona iʻoa Oregon; Oregonian. Eng. Also ʻOlekona.

ʻota kik Otter. Eng.

ʻū- A prefix indicating the instrument or cause of a particular action. Dic., ext. mng. See ʻūomo, ʻūheheʻe, ʻūhili, ʻūholo uila, ʻūhōloʻa, etc.

ʻuao kik/ham Referee, umpire; to referee. Dic. Also ʻuao haʻuki. See entry below and kanaka makaʻala ʻupena.

ʻuao ham To arbitrate. Ma kekahi mau ʻano hihia o kekahi hui me nā poʻe limahana, na kekahi luna hoʻokolokolo e ʻuao. In some disputes between a company and the employees, a judge will arbitrate. Dic. Ka ʻuao ʻana. Arbitration.

ʻuala Mākala ʻuala. Biceps, i.e. the muscle of the front of the upper arm.

ʻuala kahiki See entries below. Kipi uala kahiki. Potato chip.

ʻuala kahiki koli·koli kik Hash-brown potatoes. Lit., whittled potato. Also ʻuala kolikoli.

ʻuala kahiki pepei·ao kik Scalloped potatoes. Lit., potatoes (like) scallops. Also ʻuala. pepeiao.

ʻuala koli·koli See ʻuala kahiki kolikoli.

ʻuala pepei·ao See ʻuala kahiki pepeiao.

ʻuiki uila kik Fuse. Lit., electric fuse. Pahu ʻuiki uila. Fuse box.

ʻuiki ʻā kik Filament, as in a light bulb. Lit., wick (for) lighting. Kukui ʻuiki ʻā. Incandescent light.

ʻui·ʻuiki See nalo ʻuiʻuiki.

ʻū·omo kik Sorbent, an absorbent material such as used in chromatography. Comb. ʻū- + omo. See omo.

ʻū·omo ikehu lā kik Solar panel. Lit., instrument (for) sucking solar energy.

ʻū·hā See mākala kaʻakepa ʻūhā, mākala ʻūhā.

ʻū·hā moa kik Chicken thigh. See pālaumoa.

ʻuhane Aʻo kahua ʻuhane. Spiritually-based learning.

ʻū·heheʻe kik Solvent. Comb. ʻū- + heheʻe. See mea heheʻe. ʻŪheheʻe wai. Aqueous, i.e. having water as a solvent, in science. Māʻōʻāna ʻūheheʻe wai. Aqueous solution.

ʻū·hili kik Bat, club, racket. Comb. ʻū- + hili. ʻUhili kolepa. Golf club.

ʻū·hini kik Grasshopper. Dic.

ʻū·hini·hone Pāpapa ʻūhinihone. Honey locust bean.

ʻū·hini nēnē kik Cricket. Lit., chirping cricket. ʻŪhini nēnē kahakai. Beach cricket. ʻŪhini nēnē pele. Lava cricket.

ʻū·hini·pule kik Praying mantis. Lit., praying grasshopper.

ʻū·holo uila kik Electrode. Lit., instrument (for) conducting electricity. ʻŪholo uila ʻāne. Anode, i.e. the positive electrode in an electrical circuit. ʻŪholo uila ʻine. Cathode, i.e. the negative electrode in an electric circuit.

ʻū·hō·loʻa kik Dispenser, i.e. a dispensing container of any kind. Comb. ʻū- + hōloʻa. See entries below and hōloʻa. ʻŪhōloʻa kāwele pepa. Paper towel dispenser. ʻŪhōloʻa kopa. Soap dispenser.

ʻū·hō·loʻa kaka·lina kik Carburetor, as in an internal-combustion engine. Lit., gasoline dispenser.

 

ʻū·hō·loʻa mā·ʻō·ʻāna kik Buret, i.e. a precision-made piece of glassware used to measure and deliver accurate volumes of solutions, in science. Lit., solution dispenser.

ʻū·hū kik Enzyme. Comb. ʻū- + hū.

ʻū·kaomi hano kui kik Syringe plunger. Comb. ʻū- + kaomi + hano kui. Also ʻūkaomi, ʻūkōmi, ʻūkōmi hano kui. Cf. pāuma.

ʻū·kake uila kik Commutator, i.e. a switch on a motor running on direct current that causes the current to reverse every half turn. Lit., instrument (for) slipping electricity back and forth.

ʻukē heh To swing, as a pendulum. Dic. See uleʻo. Wā ʻukē. Period of a pendulum.

ʻū·kele kik Mud. Dic. Also lepo pohō.

ʻUke·lena iʻoa Ukraine. Eng.

ʻū·kōmi See ʻūkaomi hano kui.

ʻuku·lele kik ʻUkulele. Dic. See entries below. For parts, see kaula, nīʻau, nīʻau liʻiliʻi, nīʻau nui, papa kī, wā, ʻau, ʻōpū.

ʻuku·lele Ohta-san kik Ohta-san ʻukulele.

ʻuku·lele hā·ʻoi kik Baritone ʻukulele. See hāʻoi.

ʻuku·lele leo ʻekahi kik Soprano ʻukulele. See leo ʻekahi.

ʻuku·lele leo ʻekolu kik Tenor ʻukulele. See leo ʻekolu.

ʻuku·lele Liliʻu kik Liliʻu ʻukulele.

ʻuku·lele pahu kī·kā kik Cigar-box ʻukulele.

ʻuku·lele pū·niu kik Coconut shell ʻukulele.

ʻuku·lele ʻea honu kik Turtle shell ʻukulele.

ʻuku·lele ʻelua puka kik Double-hole ʻukulele. Lit., ʻukulele (with) two holes.

ʻuku·lele ʻewalu kaula kik Eight-string ʻukulele.

ʻuku·lele ʻokia kik Cutaway ʻukulele. See ʻokia.

ʻuku wai kik Daphnia. Lit., water flea.

ʻula Ke Kai ʻUla. Red Sea.

ʻū·lau kik Spatula, pancake turner. Comb. ʻū- + lau (flat instrument). See ʻali ʻūlau. ʻUlau kahi. Rubber spatula.

ʻula·kai·ano kik Anthocyanin, i.e. a kind of pigment producing blue to red coloring in flowers and plants. Comb. ʻula + kyanos (Greek, blue).

ʻulā·liʻi kik Measles. Dic.

ʻula mā·kuʻe ʻaʻ Magenta. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻula·ʻula Manu ʻulaʻula. Cardinal. Also manu mākaʻi.

ʻulea kik Urea. Eng.

ʻulī·keke kik Baby rattle. Sh. ʻulīʻulī + nakeke. Lina ʻulīkeke. Tambourine.

ʻū·lili kik Whistle, as a referee's. Dic.

ʻū·lili kik Railing support, balluster. Dic. Also hūlili. Cf. paehumu.

ʻū·lou kik Bonding instrument. Comb. ʻū- + lou.

ʻulu Mākala ʻulu. Gastrocnemius or calf muscle of the anterior of the lower leg.

ʻū·lū ham To pack, as a suitcase. Wilcox: u-lu.

ʻUlu·kuae iʻoa Uruguay; Uruguayan. Eng. Also ʻUruguae.

ʻū·mau·paʻa kik Component, constituent. Comb. ʻū- + maupaʻa.

ʻume kik Drawer. Dic., ext. mng. See pahu ʻume.

ʻume kik Fermata, i.e. the symbol placed over a note, chord, or rest indicating the extension of duration longer than the indicated time value, in music. Dic.

ʻume·kau·maha kik Gravity. Dic. Mīkini hoʻopau ʻumekaumaha. Antigravity machine. Piko ʻumekaumaha. Center of gravity. ʻUmekaumaha māiki. Microgravity. ʻUmekaumaha ʻole. Zero gravity.

 

ʻume·lau·oho kik Capillary. Comb. ʻume + lauoho. Paipuliʻi ʻumelauoho. Capillary pipette. Wai ʻumelauoho. Capillary water.

ʻume mā·kē·neki kik Magnetism. Lit., magnet attraction.

ʻume niniu ham Centripetal, i.e. acting in a direction toward a center. Lit., spinning attraction. Cf. lele niniu. Manehu ʻume niniu. Centripetal force.

ʻumi See entries below and hapa ʻumi.

ʻumi ham To pressure, in basketball. ʻUmi nui ʻia ʻo Karl Malone e ʻekolu mea kūpale i nā minuke hope loa o ka hoʻokūkū. Karl Malone usually gets pressured by three defenders in the last few minutes of the game. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻumi·ā·pau kik Damping-off, i.e. a diseased condition of seedlings or cuttings caused by fungi and characterized by wilting or rotting. Comb. ʻumi + ā + pau.

ʻumi kapu·aʻi See laina ʻumi kapuaʻi, ʻaʻena ʻumi kapuaʻi.

ʻū·miʻi ham To give a severe electric shock. ʻO ka noho ʻūmiʻi kekahi ʻano o ka hoʻopaʻi kū i ka make. The electric chair is one form of capital punishment. Mān. Cf. miki, omo. See entries below.

ʻū·miʻi ham To staple. Niʻihau. See kui ʻūmiʻi pepa, mea ʻūmiʻi pepa, mea wehe ʻūmiʻi, papa ʻūmiʻi, pihi ʻūmiʻi.

ʻū·miʻi ham Clamp. Dic. ʻŪmiʻi hano hoʻokolohua. Test tube clamp. ʻŪmiʻi hoʻopaʻa. Utility clamp. Cf. ʻūpā hoʻopaʻa. ʻŪmiʻi pani. Pinch clamp.

ʻū·miʻi kaula kik Capo, as used on a fretted instrument to raise the pitch of all strings. Lit., string clamp.

ʻū·miʻi·lau kik Planthopper (Oliarus tamehameha). Comb. ʻūmiʻi + lau. Cf. ʻūmiʻikō (dic.).

ʻū·miʻi lau·oho ham Bobby pin. Niʻihau.

ʻū·miʻi·nalo kik Venus flytrap. Comb. ʻūmiʻi + nalo.

ʻū·miʻi ʻili·kuapo ham Belt buckle. Also ʻūmiʻi.

ʻumi·ʻumi See pakuhi pahu me ka ʻumiʻumi.

ʻumi·ʻumi lehe·lehe kik Moustache. Lit., lip beard. Cf. ʻumiʻumi ʻauae.

ʻumi·ʻumi ʻau·ae kik Beard, excluding the moustache. Usu. ʻumiʻumi. Lit., chin beard. Cf. ʻumiʻumi lehelehe.

ʻū·mō·ʻaui kik Reactant, reagent. Comb. ʻū- + mōʻaui. See mōʻaui.

ʻū·mō·ʻaui·wawe kik Catalyst, i.e. a substance which increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being permanently changed itself. Comb. ʻūmōʻaui + wawe. Also hōʻeleu mōʻaui.

ʻuni·ona kik Union. Dic., sp. var. Kūkaʻi ʻaelike ʻuniona. Collective bargaining.

ʻū·niu heh To pivot. Sh. ʻū- + ʻōniu. See kū ʻūniu.

ʻū·nina kik Gelatin. Var. of ʻūlina, ext. mng. Cf. palaholo.

ʻunu ʻaʻ Sprained. Mān.

ʻunu·ʻunu ham To overlap, as shingles on a roof. Dic., ext. mng. Cf. piliwai.

ʻū·pā Mākala ʻūpā. Masseter muscle, i.e. the muscle that closes the jaw.

ʻū·pā hoʻo·paʻa kik Forceps. Lit., tongs (that) hold fast. Cf. ʻūmiʻi hoʻopaʻa.

ʻū·pā kā·pō·ʻai kik Compass, an instrument for describing circles or transferring measurements, in math. Comb. ʻūpā + -kāpōʻai. Cf. pānānā.

ʻū·palu ʻaʻ Mild, as a solution. E hoʻomākaukau i kekahi māʻōʻāna kopa ʻūpalu. Prepare a mild solution of soap. Dic. See ʻakika ʻūpalu kūlohelohe.

ʻupena kik Net, as of a basket on a basketball court or a volleyball net. He ʻupena wale iho nō. Nothing but net. Dic., ext. mng. Ua ʻupena ke kinopōpō. Net ball, in volleyball. Niʻihau. Also

 

 

ua ʻupena. Kanaka makaʻala ʻupena. Referee, in volleyball. See ʻuao. ʻAʻena ʻupena. Net violation. ʻUpena pōpaʻipaʻi. Volleyball net.

ʻupena ʻelala kik Insect net. See entries below.

ʻupena ʻelala hoʻo·lewa lewa kik Insect fixed net, as hung in a wind corridor to catch insects. Lik, hung insect net.

ʻupena ʻelala kā·ʻeʻe kik Insect sweep net. Lit., kāʻeʻe-style net (for) insects.

ʻupena ʻelala ʻeke kik Insect bag net, as for collecting insects from a small bush. Lit., bag insect net.

ʻū·pī·huʻa kik Styrofoam. Lit., foam sponge. Also panua.

ʻū·piki ham Trap, in basketball; to make such a play. Dic., ext. mng.

ʻū·piki lima kik Handcuffs. Dic.

ʻū·pī·lā·ʻau kik Cork, the material or the tree. Lit., wooden sponge.

ʻū·pī·ʻū ʻaʻ Spongy, as leaves of the pānini. Comb. ʻūpī + ʻū-.

ʻū·poho kik Bagpipe. Dic. Also pila ʻūpoho.

ʻū·poʻi ham To dunk (the ball), in basketball. Dic., ext. mng. Also pakā. Cf. pākī.

ʻū·ʻoki puni uila kik Circuit breaker, i.e. a device which automatically interrupts electric current before wires in a circuit get too hot. Lit., instrument (which) breaks electric circuit.

ʻuʻuku Kākoʻo hapa ʻuʻuku. Affirmative action. ʻAoʻao hapa ʻuʻuku. Minority party, in politics. ʻAha koi pohō ʻuʻuku. Small-claims court, small-debts court.

ʻUgana iʻoa Uganda; Ugandan. Eng.

ʻUru·guae iʻoa Uruguay; Uruguayan. Eng. Also ʻUlukuae.

ʻUse·peki·kana iʻoa Uzbekistan. Eng.

ʻŪ-tā iʻoa Utah; Utahan, Utahn. Dic., sp. var. Also Mauna Pōhaku.

beta kik Beta. Eng. Huna beta. Beta particle, in chemistry.

butane kik Butane. Eng.

 

 

C

CD kik CD, compact disk (pronounced sēdē). Eng. Also sēdē; pā CD, pā sēdē (preceded by ke).

Dakota Hema iʻoa South Dakota; South Dakotan. Eng. Also Kakoka Hema.

Dek. Abbreviation for Dekemapa (December). See Kekemapa.

Dela·uea iʻoa Delaware; Delawarean. Dic., sp. var. Also Kelauea.

Dene·maka iʻoa Denmark; Dane; Danish. Dic. Also Kenemaka.

diazi·nona kik Diazinon. Eng.

dieli·dirina kik Dieldrin, a kind of insecticide. Eng. Cf. ʻalidirina. See lāʻau make.

dio·kesa·side kik Dioxide. Eng. Sulufura diokesaside. Sulfur dioxide. Naikokene diokesaside. Nitrogen dioxide.

Dibuti iʻoa Djibouti. Eng.

disuli·faside kik Disulfide. Eng. Karabona disulifaside. Carbon disulfide.

Faka·lana Ka pae moku ʻo Fakalana. Falkland Islands, Falklands.

Sao·tome me Pani·kipe iʻoa Sao Tome and Principe. Eng. Ka mokupuni ʻo Saotome me Panikipe. Sao Tome and Principe Island.

sala·mena kik Salamander. Eng. Also kalamena.

Sana Helena Mauna Sana Helena. Mount Saint Helens. Also Mauna Kana Helena.

Sape·nika Liona iʻoa The huge Sphinx found near the pyramids at Giza in Egypt. ʻAkahi nō a pau ka hoʻoponopono ʻia ʻana o Sapenika Liona ma ʻAikupita. The work of renovation on the Sphinx in Egypt has just been completed. Lit., lion sphinx (Eng.). Cf. kanaka kino liona.

sawana kik Savanna, i.e. a tropical or subtropical grassland containing scattered trees. Eng.

sasa·palasa kik Sassafras. Eng.

satano·usa kolori·side kik Stannous chloride. Eng.

Sekele iʻoa Seychelles. Eng. Ka pae moku ʻo Sekele. Seychelles Islands.

Seko·tia iʻoa Scotland; Scot, Scots, Scottish. Dic. Also Kekokia.

semi·nā kik Seminar. Eng.

Sene·kala iʻoa Senegal. Eng.

Sepa·nia iʻoa Spain. Dic. Also Kepania.

sē·dē See CD.

Siela·leone iʻoa Sierra Leone. Eng.

sila kik Seal. Mān. Papa Hana Hoʻopakele Sila. Seal Recovery Program. Sila Hawaiʻi. Hawaiian monk seal. Sila pūhuluhulu. Fur seal. ʻOhana sila. Pinniped, i.e. any of the suborder of aquatic mammals including the seal and walrus.

silaka kik Silica. Eng. Palaholo silaka g. Silica gel g, a powder used as the sorbent layer in thin-layer chromatography (pronounced palaholo silaka gā).

sili·kone kik Silicon. Eng.

Sili·lanaka iʻoa Sri Lanka. Eng.

Sina·poa iʻoa Singapore. Eng.

sī·wila Kānāwai sīwila. Civil law. Also kānāwai kīwila.

Sibe·ria iʻoa Siberia, Siberian. Eng. Ke kai ʻo Siberia Hikina. East Siberian Sea.

-side Suffix in chemical compounds and terms: -ide.

siri·ala kik Cereal. Eng. Also kiliala.

solono·kiuma kik Strontium. Eng.

Solo·wakia iʻoa Slovakia. Eng.

Soma·lia iʻoa Somalia; Somalian. Eng.

sū·kini kik Zucchini. Eng.

sula·fahate kik Sulfate. Eng. Kupuriku sulafahate. Cupric sulfate.
